article_title: National Review to hit Christie on N.J. record
article_text:
On Media Blog Archives Select Date… December, 2015 November, 2015 October, 2015 September, 2015 August, 2015 July, 2015 June, 2015 May, 2015 April, 2015 March, 2015 February, 2015 January, 2015

National Review to hit Christie on N.J. record

The National Review will publish a cover story this week about Chris Christie's failure to revive New Jersey's economy, editor Rich Lowry told the On Media blog on Wednesday.

The story is a setback to Christie's effort to court conservatives ahead of his anticipated presidential bid, coming as it does from an influential conservative magazine rather than a mainstream or liberal outlet that can be dismissed as unfavorable or biased. In an interview with CNBC last year, Christie said he loved National Review and read it "all the time." Whereas in a recent appearance at CPAC, Christie slammed The New York Times as an outlet that was trying to "kill" him "every day."

The report, which will appear in the issue that hits newsstands Friday, is by Steven Malanga, a contributing editor to City Journal. The cover features Christie and the New Jersey Capitol in a sinking boat, with dollar bills pouring overboard. The headline: "Chris Christie's New Jersey problem."

"[S]ince winning reelection easily in 2013, Christie has watched his reputation tumble both in New Jersey and nationwide," Malanga reports. "This is partly the result of the political fallout from the so-called Bridgegate scandal ... But, in addition, the governor’s efforts at cleaning up the state’s multitude of fiscal messes and recharging its economy have stalled, prompting criticisms that he isn’t doing enough to revive New Jersey."

At its conclusion, Malanga notes that "Christie’s administration could have achieved so much more. It might have demonstrated to the state’s cynical and beleaguered voters that it is possible to change the culture of Trenton, to overturn the greedy, profligate, dysfunctional politics that has so consistently earned new Jersey a reputation as one of the worst-managed states, and to set state government on a path toward financial stability and regulatory sanity."

"But Christie still has time to demonstrate just how destructive years of tax-borrow-and-spend policies have been," Malanga adds, "and this would be a real achievement."
